title: 113_hr2884
content: The Act may be cited as the "Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2013" and establishes the Witness Protection Grant Program. The Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2013 establishes a program where the Attorney General provides competitive grants to State, tribal, and local governments to support programs that protect or assist witnesses in court proceedings involving serious crimes or gangs. Applicants are evaluated based on their infrastructure. The Witness Security and Protection Grant Program Act of 2013 evaluates applicants based on their lack of infrastructure to support witness protection programs, prevalence of witness intimidation, cases not prosecuted due to intimidation, homicides and serious crimes per capita, presence of organized crime, and other criteria determined by the Attorney General. Technical assistance is provided by the Attorney General from allocated funds. The Attorney General provides technical assistance to grant recipients for establishing witness protection programs. Recipients must submit reports evaluating their programs, and the Attorney General develops best practices based on these reports. The Attorney General develops best practice models for witness protection programs, including safety, relocation, financial assistance, and other related services. These models are disseminated to State, tribal, and local governments within one year. Congress encourages the use of these best practices by governments. The Attorney General develops best practice models for witness protection programs, including safety, relocation, and financial assistance. The Federal share of program costs funded by grants under this section is limited to 75 percent. Information deemed law enforcement sensitive or a threat to national security is not required to be disclosed. The non-Federal share for a program grant may be in the form of in-kind contributions, not exceeding 50%. The Attorney General can use up to 5% of funds for administrative costs. Geographic distribution is ensured in grant allocation. The Attorney General must ensure equitable distribution of witness protection programs across the US and consider applicants from urban and rural areas. Reports to Congress are required on program implementation and funding. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2014-2018.
